utterances: So check it for whiskers.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Okay.
And will the new plans - I mean, will he be able to buy exchange plans if we have a bad insurance plan offered through our employer?
Not necessarily.
That's another big issue about who the exchanges will be open to.
It depends, again, on the size of your insurer but most people will not actually be able - at least initially, the exchanges will not be open to people unless they're in small businesses.
Becky, thank you.
Good luck.
Thank you very much.
Bye-bye.
We're talking with NPR health policy correspondent Julie Rovner.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I think you don't recover from that - from losing someone like that.
He has two daughters.
One is 24 and the other's 28.
(Spanish spoke).
And here's an email question.
This is from Diane(ph) in Spearfish, South Dakota.
I am covered under my husband's plan at his work.
He works for a global mining company.
I understand his company's plan is considered self-insured; therefore, they do not have to offer coverage for children until the age of 26.
Self-insured companies are not required to provide this feature under health reform?
Mm-mm.
No, that's not true.
I mean, that's just a self-insured ERISA plan, but this covers ERISA plans, they do have to abide by these rules.

The ones - the people who got caught by this who didn't have to abide by this are the people in TRICARE, one of the military plans, who were so anxious to be excluded from all of this that they got themselves excluded from all of these new rules and then suddenly came clamoring back to complain because suddenly their kids who are age 22 to 26 weren't being covered.
So, well, be careful what you ask for.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Exactly.
Okay.
Let's see if we can go next to - this is Barbara(ph), Barbara with us from Narragansett in Rhode Island.
Hi.

Yes, my husband is a federal employee, and we received a letter last week from Blue Cross, which is probably the only insurer in the state that they were not going to provide coverage for federal employees.
You know, we have to go to open season and then select some other program.
Are companies doing this, dropping a whole bunch of people because they don't want to insure them?
You mean they're going to stop providing coverage in the state?
Or...
For federal employees, correct.
Oh.
I hadn't heard that.
I mean, but company - I mean, companies do, although I don't know that - did they say it was because of the new law?
Or...
They didn't say.
They just say effective, you know, with open season, you must select another coverage.
And Blue Cross/Blue Shield is practically the only insurer in the state.
We'd have to go with a national plan, but I was surprised to see it because there's so many people - federal employees are covered by Blue Cross in the state.
Yeah, I had not heard that.
I was...
Last week - the letter was out last week.
Yeah.
I was not aware that they were leaving the...
We're a little state.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yeah.
That I know.
The federal government is a large employer, though.
Yes, they are.
Yes, it is.
And there are many health plans in the federal benefits plan.
I wanted to pass that on as that's something that's happening.
I would look into that.
All right, thank you.
Bye-bye.
Bye.
And finally, Julie, we talked a little bit about the politics of this before.
We mentioned some of those polls that have been done.
One of them is about the general popularity of the health care reform.
This could play a part in November as people consider that, and the numbers are pretty interesting.
Yes, they are.
You know, well, one thing, it should bear saying that for all the focus on this this year, health care is not really up towards the top of people's voting issues.
The economy is playing a much, much, much larger role.

But one of the interesting things, as much as the Republicans are trying to make hay out of the people's discontent with this law, you know, was this poll by the Associated Press over the weekend that found that four in 10 people who don't - four in 10 people say that they think this law didn't go far enough, which is twice as many people who think that the law went too far.
So there's actually a fair number of people who wish that the law had done more.
So there really is a lot of very mixed opinion about what this does.
And I think, really, what's important here is that the health care system is so complex - and I think we've seen that just from the questions.
It affects everybody differently.
People are still confused because it's inherently confusing.
Julie Rovner, thanks very much for helping us lose a little bit of that confusion.
Anyway, we appreciate your time.
We'll keep at it.
NPR health policy correspondent Julie Rovner, with us here in Studio 3A.
Coming up, the decline of the American dream.
What does that phrase mean to you?
Email us: talk@npr.org.
Gregory Rodriguez will join us on the Opinion Page next.
Stay with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
The Iraq Study Group is expected to release its independent assessment of the war next month.
As this bipartisan panel hammers out its recommendations the Pentagon is finalizing its own review of how to handle the conflict in Iraq.
The two panels may very well disagree on whether U.S.
forces should stay or leave.
But analysts say both groups will share at least one common thread: The United States needs to do a better job of training Iraqi troops.
NPR's Tom Bowman reports.
There are now about 4,000 U.S.
troops in Iraq training local forces.
During the summer the top American trainer in Iraq, Major General Martin Dempsey, was asked if more trainers were needed.
I wouldn't say a dramatic increase in that number although, we'll do what we have to do to get the Iraqi security forces capable.
But Dempsey's boss, General John Abizaid, had a greater sense of urgency when he appeared before Congress just a few weeks ago.
We must significantly increase our ability to help the Iraqi army by putting more American troops with Iraqi units in military transition teams.
So what's changed?
American military leaders and the authors of upcoming reviews reportedly have concluded that the training of Iraqi forces is not progressing fast enough.
And they say Iraq will need tens of thousands of more troops.
